awd_titl_txt: SusChEM: An integrated framework for process design, control and scheduling [PAROC]
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project aims for an innovative shift in addressing three common tasks performed by process engineers: design, scheduling, and control of process systems. These tasks are typically performed independently of each other, without taking into consideration the interactions and trade-offs amongst them. The development and use of novel strategies, procedures, and tools for decision making for process system engineering has the potential, as part of smart manufacturing and process improvement efforts, to contribute significantly to a sustainable future. The primary aim of this research project is to provide a useful conceptual framework and software tool for the integration of design, control and scheduling tasks. The framework and software platform is being applied to the optimization of a residential combined cooling, heating and power generation network system. The project findings are being incorporated into graduate courses at Texas A&M University. The developed tool is being deployed as an open access software tool for the benefit of the academic and industrial communities.
 
The integration of process design, control and scheduling remains an open grand challenge in process systems engineering. While significant research efforts have been made in the last twenty years to sequentially integrate design with control, and more recently control with scheduling, a generally accepted methodology to unify the field is still lacking. The multi-scale framework being developed features (1) a high-fidelity dynamic model representation, also involving global sensitivity analysis, parameter estimation and mixed integer dynamic optimization capabilities; (2) a suite/toolbox of model approximation methods; (3) a host of multi-parametric programming solvers for mixed continuous/integer problems; (4) a state-space modeling representation capability for scheduling and control problems; and (5) an advanced toolkit for multi-parametric/explicit Model Predictive Control and moving horizon reactive scheduling problems. The intellectual merit of the activity lies in the integration of the three tasks (design, control and scheduling) within a unified multiscale framework and in the ability to acquire optimal operation policies, optimal model based controllers and optimal designs of process systems through a single optimization formulation.  Additionally, there is merit in the capability to close the loop with a cross validation of the outcomes with the original model, ensuring optimal and stable operation.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we developed a complete theory, framework, and software prototypes that aim to replace the current understanding of addressing the process design and operational optimization problems in chemical processes with a holistic approach to improve overall process efficiency. Existing techniques for process design, scheduling, and control decisions are applied sequentially due to the nature of their structural differences in problem formulations, objectives to achieve, and time scales they represent. Furthermore, such differences require a diverse range of skills and expertise. Lack of perfect coordination among decision layers result in suboptimal, and even infeasible operations, which increases the capital and operating expenditures of an enterprise, disrupts the supply chain of production, and increases the energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions. Our developed theory integrates these decision making mechanisms using the state of the art modeling and optimization techniques including multi-parametric programming and global optimization to leverage their synergistic interactions and increase process efficiency by simultaneously considering multiple layers of decisions. Applicability of the theory was tested both on continuous and batch modes of operation, two of the most predominant in the process industry. Specific applications studied in this project included reactors, bioreactors, distillation columns, reactive distillation columns, and combined heat and power units. Our developed theory has shown to reduce the size of processing units while reducing the operating costs related to raw material utilization and energy consumption. In addition, integrated operating strategies has performed faster and more stable responses under rapid changes in market conditions such as rapidly changing fluctuating energy prices. The knowledge accumulated with this project has been disseminated in multiple peer reviewed journal articles and academic conferences. We have developed software prototypes that enable industrial practitioners and academics to apply the framework on their own problems, with suitable links to existing process simulation and optimization tools. Portions of the gathered knowledge has been included in the curriculums of the Advanced Process Optimization course, offered in the Department of Chemical Engineering, and the Master of Science in Energy program at Texas A&M University. The entirety of these theoretical and practical advances will be published in a single monograph, which the community in general can benefit.
